question: In Nature journal's Scientific Reports conference proceedings from 2012, in the article that did not mention plasmons or plasmonics, what nano-compound is studied? Don't use the prefix nano in your answer if there is one.

Found 3 web results with content:

1. Diamond photonic crystal slab: Leaky modes and modified ... - Nature
   URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/srep00914
   Site: nature.com
   Summary: Here we present a detailed study of the leaky modes of a nanocrystalline diamond (NCD) PhC slab by investigating polarization resolved photonic band diagrams.
   Content: Diamond photonic crystal slab: Leaky modes and modified photoluminescence emission of surface-deposited quantum dots | Scientific Reports Skip to main content Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain

Advertisement View all journals Search Log in Content Explore content About the journal Publish with us Sign up for alerts RSS feed nature scientific reports conference proceedings article Diamond photonic crystal slab: Leaky modes and modified photoluminescence emission of surface-deposited quantum dots Download PDF Download PDF Conference Proceeding Open access Published: 03 December 2012 Diamond photonic crystal slab: Leaky modes and modified photoluminescence emission of surface-deposited quantum dots Lukáš Ondič 1 , 2 , 3 , Oleg Babchenko 1 , Marián Varga 1 , Alexander Kromka 1 , Jiří Čtyroký 4 & … Ivan Pelant 1 Show authors Scientific Reports volume 2 , Article number: 914 ( 2012 ) Cite this article 69k Accesses 19 Citations 5 Altmetric Metrics details Subjects Materials science Optical physics Optics and photonics Optical spectroscopy Abstract Detailed analysis of a band diagram of a photonic crystal (PhC) slab prepared on a nano-diamond layer is presented. Even though the PhC is structurally imperfect, the existence of leaky modes, determined both theoretically and experimentally in the broad spectral region, implies that an efficient light interaction with a material periodicity occurs in the sample. It is shown that the luminescence emission spectrum of a light source placed directly on the PhC surface can be modified by employing the optical modes of the studied structure. We stress also the impact of intrinsic optical losses of the nan

1. Efficient light coupling for optically excited high-density ...
   URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/srep00915
   Site: nature.com
   Summary: by A Mustonen · Cited by 34 — Efficient light coupling for optically excited high-density metallic nanotip arrays. Sci Rep 2, 915 (2012). https://doi.org/10.1038 ...
   Content: Efficient light coupling for optically excited high-density metallic nanotip arrays | Scientific Reports Skip to main content Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain

Advertisement View all journals Search Log in Content Explore content About the journal Publish with us Sign up for alerts RSS feed nature scientific reports conference proceedings article Efficient light coupling for optically excited high-density metallic nanotip arrays Download PDF Download PDF Conference Proceeding Open access Published: 03 December 2012 Efficient light coupling for optically excited high-density metallic nanotip arrays Anna Mustonen 1 , Paul Beaud 2 , Eugenie Kirk 1 , Thomas Feurer 3 & … Soichiro Tsujino 1 Show authors Scientific Reports volume 2 , Article number: 915 ( 2012 ) Cite this article 34k Accesses 26 Citations 2 Altmetric Metrics details Subjects Applied physics Optical physics Optics and photonics Ultrafast photonics Abstract Ultrafast electron pulses can be produced from sharp metallic tips illuminated by femtosecond near infrared laser pulses. Use of an array of metallic nanotips for high charge bunch generation and accelerator applications is also feasible but the small fraction of the emitter tip area limits the quantum efficiency. We therefore propose a submicron-pitch, high-density nanotip array device with a gate electrode, that can support surface-plasmon polaritons. From a theoretical analysis for a device with an asymmetric emitter position, a factor ~30 increased array quantum efficiency is demonstrated. trajectory.actor_reasoning:
Among the four 2012 Scientific Reports conference proceedings, three explicitly mention plasmon/plasmonic; the remaining article is “Diamond photonic crystal slab…,” which studies nanodiamond—so without the prefix, the compound is diamond.

FINAL ANSWER: diamond

args.query: Diamond photonic crystal slab nanodiamond Scientific Reports 2012 nano-diamond layer

messages.name: enhanced_search

messages.content:
Among the four 2012 Scientific Reports conference proceedings, three explicitly mention plasmon/plasmonic; the remaining article is “Diamond photonic crystal slab…,” which studies nanodiamond—so without the prefix, the compound is diamond.

FINAL ANSWER: diamond
